title: 111_hr2785
content: The Act titled "Health Care Paperwork Reduction and Fraud Prevention Act of 2009" includes the establishment of a National Bipartisan Commission on Billing Codes and Forms Simplification. The Commission on Health Care Billing Codes and Forms Simplification is established to recommend standardized and simplified forms, reduce billing codes, and reform regulatory processes under the Medicare program. The Commission on Health Care Billing Codes and Forms Simplification, established under title XVIII of the Social Security Act, aims to provide guidance to suppliers and providers of services, including physicians and ambulance services, for proper claims submission under Medicare. It also focuses on simplifying electronic forms and payments of the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services while ensuring patient privacy. The Commission consists of 17 members, with four appointed by the President. The Commission on Health Care Billing Codes and Forms Simplification, established under title XVIII of the Social Security Act, consists of 17 members appointed by various officials. The President appoints four members, the Senate majority leader appoints six (with consultation from the minority leader), the Speaker of the House appoints six (with consultation from the minority leader), and one member serves as Chairman appointed jointly by the President, Senate majority leader, and Speaker of the House. The Commission on Health Care Billing Codes and Forms Simplification, established under title XVIII of the Social Security Act, consists of 17 members appointed by various officials. Members of the Commission shall be appointed within 90 days of the enactment of this Act. The Commission will operate under bipartisan provisions similar to those of the National Bipartisan Commission on the Future of Medicare. A report with approved recommendations must be submitted to the President and Congress by December 31, 2009. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting the report. SEC. 3. EDUCATION OF PHYSICIANS AND PROVIDERS ON MEDICARE PAYMENTS. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will establish a process for physicians to request assistance with Medicare billing codes. The carrier must respond within 30 days with the correct information. Written requests can be used as proof in audits, except for cases of fraudulent billing. The Administrator of the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services will restore a toll-free hotline for physicians to inquire about the Medicare program. Appropriations are authorized for this purpose. Definitions for "physician" and "carrier" are provided in this section. The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services Administrator will establish a toll-free hotline for physician inquiries about the Medicare program. This pertains to physicians and carriers defined in section 1842(f) of the Social Security Act. Policy development for E&M guidelines under the Medicare program will be established. The Administrator of the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services must follow specific steps before implementing new evaluation and management guidelines under the Medicare program, including physician assessment, pilot projects in different regions, and meeting specified objectives. Pilot projects under this subsection must be of sufficient length for education, analysis, and assessment of E&M guidelines, conducted in consultation with medical societies. One pilot project will focus on peer review by physicians evaluating medical records for outlier services based on CPT guidelines. The pilot projects will assess the impact of potential E&M guidelines on different physician practices and compliance costs. A report on meeting objectives must be submitted within 6 months after the conclusion of all pilot projects. The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services will report to specific committees on pilot projects' outcomes related to E&M guidelines. Objectives include improving documentation accuracy, reducing administrative burdens, and streamlining non-clinical documentation. The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services will report on pilot projects' outcomes related to E&M guidelines, focusing on improving documentation accuracy, reducing administrative burdens, and streamlining non-clinical documentation. Definitions for "physician" and "carrier" are provided for clarity. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services, and the term "Medicare program" refers to the program under title XVIII of the Social Security Act. SEC. 5. OVERPAYMENTS UNDER THE MEDICARE PROGRAM. If a carrier conducts a post-payment audit of a physician under Medicare, they must provide the physician with a personalized notice of billing issues within 3 months. The notice should offer suggestions on how to resolve the billing problem. Physicians are allowed to repay Medicare overpayments without penalty or interest within 3 months of notification, as long as the overpayment was not due to fraudulent actions. If a physician discovers an overpayment before being notified by the carrier, they can reimburse Medicare without penalty. First-time billing errors may not result in fines unless fraudulent claims are involved. Carriers must inform physicians of problem claims before using extrapolation for reimbursement or penalties. Physicians can dispute carrier's charges of overpayment by submitting additional information without waiving their right to a hearing. Carriers conducting pre-payment screens must not delay reimbursements for more than one month after a post-payment audit.
